title: 112_s965
content: The "Family Act of 2011" is the short title of this Act. It includes findings as outlined in Section 2. Congress finds that infertility is recognized as a disease by the World Health Organization and is considered an emerging public health priority by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Approximately 3,000,000 individuals have infertility according to the CDC. Medical insurance coverage for infertility treatments is limited, with only 8 states having laws requiring comprehensive coverage. According to Mercer's 2005 National Survey of Employer-Sponsored Health Plans, in vitro fertilization is covered by 19 percent of large employer-sponsored health plans and only 11 percent of small employer-sponsored health plans, even in States with coverage mandates. Out-of-pocket expenses for these treatments are significant. Section 3 introduces a new tax credit for certain infertility treatments under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A new tax credit allows eligible individuals to claim 50% of qualified infertility treatment expenses, up to a limit of $13,360 per year. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $150,000. The tax credit for infertility treatment expenses is reduced based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income exceeding $150,000, with adjustments made for certain income exclusions. No double benefit is allowed if a deduction or credit is taken under another provision. No credit under subsection (a) for expenses if reimbursement or funds are received from Federal, State, or local programs. No credit if payment or reimbursement is received from insurance for the expense. The credit allowed for expenses under subsection (a) is limited if reimbursement is received from insurance. The credit for any taxable year cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27. The credit allowed under subsection (a) is limited if reimbursement is received from insurance. For any taxable year, the credit cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, minus the credits allowable under this subpart and section 27. Excess credits can be carried forward to the succeeding year. Excess credits under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the next taxable year if the limitation imposed by subsection (b)(4) is exceeded. The credit allowable under subsection (a) can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year, with a limitation of no carry forward beyond the 5th taxable year after the credit arose. Qualified infertility treatment expenses refer to amounts paid for such treatments. Qualified infertility treatment expenses are defined as amounts paid for in vitro fertilization treatment administered by a licensed medical practitioner for a diagnosis of infertility. Treatment expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before medical procedures that may cause infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of whether a diagnosis of infertility is made later. Expenses for fertility preservation procedures conducted before procedures that may result in infertility are considered qualified infertility treatment expenses, regardless of later diagnosis. Infertility is defined as the inability to conceive or carry a pregnancy to live birth, excluding iatrogenic infertility caused by medical treatments like chemotherapy or surgery. For tax purposes, an eligible individual is someone diagnosed with infertility by a licensed physician in the US. Married taxpayers must file joint returns. Married taxpayers must file joint returns. Dollar limitations in subsection (b)(1) will be adjusted for inflation starting in 2013. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) will be increased for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) will be increased for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002 by a cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. If the increased amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(i) will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002. Conforming amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Section 23A amends various sections of the Internal Revenue Code, including 36C, 25, and 1400C, by adding references to itself. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2011, including changes to sections 23A and 25D of the Internal Revenue Code.
